definition: to bite words and chew characters (idiom); punctilious about minutiae of wording
letter/symbol/character/word/CL:個|个[ge4]/courtesy or style name traditionally given to males aged 20 in dynastic China

sentences.english: The legal pavane included pages of discussion of whether begging is speech, or begging is behavior.
sentences.chinese: 判令里连篇累牍咬文嚼字地讨论乞讨是言论还是行为。

sentences.english: And she sometimes talked about her “goals.”
sentences.chinese: 她有时还会咬文嚼字地说起她的“目标”。

sentences.english: Instead of deciding the real issue the commentator would chop logic.
sentences.chinese: 这位评论家不去解决实质问题，而总是咬文嚼字。

sentences.english: Read This Article in English With Chinese Characters
sentences.chinese: 咬文嚼字的品位一下这篇英文写的文章。

sentences.english: This may look like just semantics, but it matters.
sentences.chinese: 这个看上去可能有点咬文嚼字，但是它很重要。

definition: lit. to wave around one's bookbag (idiom)/fig. to show off one's erudition/a person who does so
lit. to quote the classics/to quote chapter and verse (idiom)
lit. 之[zhi1], 乎[hu1], 者[zhe3] and 也[ye3] (four grammatical particles of Classical Chinese) (idiom); fig. archaic expressions
lit. not requiring a detailed understanding (idiom); only looking for an overview/not bothered with the details/superficial/content with shallow understanding
old language/the Classics/Classical Chinese as a literary model, esp. in Tang and Song prose/Classical Chinese as a school subject
a bunch of nonsense/verbose and rambling
literal/word by word and phrase by phrase
